title: Man beaten up with a pumpkin because thug thought he’d stuck fingers up at him
text:
Daniel Kisiel targeted the man wrongly believing he had stuck two fingers up at him (Picture: MEN)

A man has been jailed for four years after he broke into a stranger’s flat and beat him up with a pumpkin.

Daniel Kisiel, 29, wrongly believed that his victim had stuck two fingers up at him so went on a violent attack four hours later in the early hours.

The victim was brushing his teeth at his flat in Salford, Greater Manchester, when Kisiel burst in and hit him over the head with the pumpkin shouting ‘I’m going to f**king kill you, you c**t.’

He then took a piece of wood with nails in it from the door that he had just broken and started attacking him as he curled in a ball on the floor.

Judge Anthony Cross slammed prosecutors at Manchester Crown Court for ‘grossly undercharging him’ with ABH and criminal damage rather than GBH.

Describing what happened in the run-up to the attack prosecutor Elizabeth Evans said the victim returned home at around 9pm and found Kisiel sat outside his front door:

She said: ‘He asked him whether he was waiting for somebody and received a response but couldn’t understand him.

He was jailed for four years at Manchester Crown Court but the judge said he ad been grossly undercharged (Picture: MEN)

‘The defendant stood up as if he was blocking the complainant’s way into his flat door. He described him as smelling of alcohol.

‘The defendant made a hand gesture sticking two fingers up at the male and “why did you do this?” He had no idea what he was talking about.’

Could a no-deal Brexit still happen?

They then had an argument before the victim went inside. Four hours later at 1am, he was brushing his teeth in his bathroom when he heard an ‘almighty bang’.

‘The defendant smashed his door open and came into the bathroom. He was carrying a pumpkin which he smashed over the mans head’, Ms Evans added.

‘This knocked him to the floor and the defendant was shouting ‘I’m going to f*****g kill you, you c***’.

‘The defendant had a piece of broken wood that had come off the door which had nails in it which he used to hit the complainant.

‘He then dragged him into the bedroom and started kicking his head and body as he was curled up into a ball.’

Advertisement

Kisiel only stopped attacking the man when a woman appeared and called the police. The victim was left with cuts and bruises to his eye, head, back,shoulders, arms and legs.

In an impact statement read out at court, he said he ‘should be able to feel safe in his own home’ and that he won’t feel safe now because of the fear of ‘someone coming through his door and attacking him’ again.

What happens to Brexit if Boris Johnson's deal fails?

In mitigation David Morton said his client, who has previous convictions for battery and common assaults, continues to deny the offence.

He described him as being ‘clearly focused on family’ and as being a hard-working citizen since he moved to the UK from Poland in 2009.

But Judge Anthony Cross QC described Kisiel’s attack as ‘ferocious’ and brutal’.

‘The victim would have expected that he was safe in his own home’, the judge told him while passing sentence.

‘But four hours after your first encounter, in the dead of the night, at a time when we are entitled to feel safe from intruders, he was brushing his teeth when you burst into his apartment breaking the door down and shattering the frame.

Advertisement

‘You picked up a pumpkin from somewhere and hit him with it and knocked him to the floor. You picked up a piece of wood and made about him. You struck him numerous times and he was unable to defend himself.

‘At some point during that attack you told him you wanted to kill him. You dragged him to the bedroom and began the third stage of this brutal assault. You kicked him in his head and his body.

‘The violence stopped only because a woman appeared and the police were called and you were arrested.

‘Your victim was left with the consequences of your actions. Pictures of his injuries show the ferocity of this random attack and I am satisfied that your victim suffered serious injuries.

‘You are a violent man, of that I am sure. You have demonstrates no remove whatsoever and this is a serious offence.’

Kisiel, of Great Clowes Street in Salford, was jailed for four years.
